title: 107_hr2645
content: The Motor Donor Act, also known as the National Organ Donor Registry, amends the Public Health Service Act to establish a national organ donor registry. The purposes of this subpart are to increase the number of individuals registering as organ or tissue donors, enhance information provided by Federal and State governments, and ensure timely and accurate information on individuals' donation wishes. The subpart aims to improve information on organ and tissue donation, ensure accurate recording of individuals' donation wishes, and provide grants to states for establishing donor registries through driver's license applications. The term "motor vehicle driver's license" refers to any ID issued by a state motor vehicle authority. The subpart establishes a national organ and tissue donor registry called the Registry, consisting of a database listing individuals who have expressed an intent to donate. The national organ and tissue donor registry, known as the `Registry', consists of a database with information on individuals who wish to be donors, including their name, address, date of birth, sex, height, eye color, and a unique identification number assigned by the Secretary. Coordination with states and organ procurement organizations is also outlined. The Motor Donor Act requires coordination between the Secretary and States with organ donor registries to share data and provide links to the national Registry. The Motor Donor Act mandates coordination between the Secretary and States with organ donor registries to share data and establish links with the national Registry. During the initial 4-year period, the Secretary will work with States to promote the creation of organ and tissue donor registries through the driver's license process. The Motor Donor Act requires coordination between the Secretary and States to promote organ and tissue donor registries through the driver's license process. Organ procurement organizations can access the Registry 24/7 with a password provided by the Secretary. Staff members designated by the organization can receive the password. The Motor Donor Act allows organ procurement organizations to access the Registry 24/7 using a password provided by the Secretary. Designated staff members within the organization can receive the password to access the Registry. The Secretary will disseminate a pamphlet to all U.S. citizens who filed a Federal income tax return within the prior year. Following the Motor Donor Act enactment, the Secretary will distribute a pamphlet to US citizens who filed a Federal income tax return the previous year, containing organ donation information and a website address for Registry participation. Within 4 months of online Registry enrollment, the Secretary will notify individuals of their participation. Within 4 months of enrolling in the Registry through the website, the Secretary will notify individuals of their participation. Participation in the Registry will not impact organ or tissue allocation decisions. The Registry serves as a declaration of intent for organ donation. The national practices for organ donation procurement organization apply to determining consent. The Registry is for declaring intent to donate organs, not legally binding consent. Participants can cancel their registration at any time. Individuals can cancel their participation in the Registry at any time. The Secretary will notify them of this right and promptly remove their information from the Registry. The Secretary is authorized to award grants to States with approved applications. The Secretary can remove an individual's information from the Registry if they cancel their participation. Grants are awarded to States for implementing State registries linked to driver's license applications. Each State seeking a grant must submit an application to the Secretary outlining procedures for individuals to make legally binding organ and tissue donations. Each State applying for a grant must demonstrate procedures for individuals to make legally binding organ and tissue donations, including designations made with a driver's license application. The procedures must comply with specific requirements. The State procedures for driver's license applications must comply with specific requirements, including assurances that the process will be in accordance with State law. State driver's license application allows individuals to designate themselves as organ and tissue donors. The application must comply with State law requirements. The State procedures for organ donor designation on driver's license applications require a question asking individuals if they wish to be listed in the State registry. Only affirmative responses are accepted. The State procedures mandate that only individuals who affirmatively answer a question on their driver's license application will have their organ donor preference noted in the State registry or on their license. The State procedures require forwarding information to the Registry for individuals who indicate their organ donor preference on their driver's license application within 100 days of designation. The State procedures mandate forwarding organ donor designation information to the Registry within 100 days of designation, including any changes in designation or address. Individuals who opt out of having their organ donor designation included in the State registry must be noted. The State procedures require forwarding organ donor information to the Registry within 100 days, including any changes. Individuals opting out will not have their information forwarded. Access by organ procurement organization is also specified. The State procedures mandate that information of individuals who consent to organ donation be recorded in their computer record and made accessible 24/7 to organ procurement organizations without any fees. The Secretary gives priority in awarding grants to States collaborating with organ procurement organizations. Grants awarded to a State cannot exceed $300,000. An advisory task force is established. The advisory task force on organ and tissue donation, consisting of 5 members appointed by the Secretary, is established. No grant awarded to a State shall exceed $300,000. The Task Force on organ and tissue donation consists of 5 members appointed by the Secretary based on their experience in organ donations, procurement, or transplants. The Task Force on organ and tissue donation consists of 5 members appointed by the Secretary with experience in organ donations, procurement, or transplants. At least 1 member must be a physician with transplant experience, and another member must have organ procurement experience. The Task Force on organ and tissue donation consists of 5 members appointed by the Secretary with relevant experience. Each member serves a 3-year term, with staggered terms for initial members. Vacancies in the Task Force are filled as needed. The Task Force on organ and tissue donation, appointed by the Secretary, consists of 5 members with staggered 3-year terms. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Task Force may partner with the Coalition on Donation to increase donations. The Task Force may partner with the Coalition on Donation to incorporate an outreach campaign for the Registry into the Coalition's national awareness campaign. They are required to conduct a study and submit recommendations to the Secretary within 1 year of the Motor Donor Act's enactment. The Task Force, established by the Motor Donor Act, will conduct a study and submit recommendations to the Secretary within 1 year to improve the Registry, raise public awareness about organ donation, and enhance the donation process. Members of the Task Force will not receive compensation for travel expenses. Members of the Task Force will not receive compensation for travel expenses. The Task Force, established by the Motor Donor Act, will receive per diem in lieu of subsistence while away from their homes in the performance of services. The Secretary may accept voluntary and uncompensated services of Task Force members. The Secretary may accept voluntary and uncompensated services of Task Force members, and government employees can be detailed to the Task Force without reimbursement. The Department of Health and Human Services will provide necessary administrative support to the Task Force. The Department of Health and Human Services will provide administrative support to the Task Force. Authorization of appropriations is granted for carrying out the section. Authorization of appropriations is granted for carrying out the section, with specific amounts allocated for registry and grants, as well as an awareness campaign for fiscal years 2002 through 2006. Amounts appropriated will remain available until expended. "Subpart 2--Organ Procurement" is amended in the Internal Revenue Code. Section 6103(m) of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to allow disclosure of taxpayer information to the Department of Health and Human Services for organ donor program purposes. The Department of Health and Human Services can access taxpayer information for the national organ and tissue donor registry under section 370(c) of the Public Health Service. This is necessary for contacting individuals regarding the registry. SEC. 4. CONFORMING AMENDMENTS. Subpart 2 of part H of title III of the Public Health Service Act is amended in sections 374(a), 374(d), 375(1), and 378, by replacing "this part" with "this subpart".
